Posted: July 12, 2015
PresentationOut There Somewhere is possibly one of the most challenging, unique and intriguing platformers you'll ever play, as it puts you in control of a little alien, stranded on an unknown planet after his ship has crashed as a result of a space battle between him and his nemesis, Grigori, who ended up on the same planet as you, changing the lives of the planet's inhabitants. With that being said, you'll soon be on your way to recover the core needed for your ship to function again and finish what you've started, but to do so you'll have to traverse a long way, filled with danger, friendly and foe aliens and plenty of secrets. While the intelligent life on the planet will mostly only complain about how Grigori has influenced their lives since his arrival, and occasionally open a door for you or give you a hint to where you should head next, the more barbaric enemies simply known as monsters will often stand between you and your next objective, forcing you to think up different strategy on the move. While the plot isn't the most unique one and it certainly doesn't have any twists along the way, it is pleasing to see how many different areas and secrets you can find along the way, some which will often lead to items that will make your journey easier, such as abandoned cores or ancient alien artifacts. There is a certain lack of character development when it comes to the intelligent aliens, which will only interact with you with the same line of dialogue, which in most cases doesn't make any sense.Rating: 7GameplayAs any platformer you'll want to play, gameplay is the key element for an unforgettable experience, and in this aspect, Out There Somewhere brings some interesting concepts to the table, such as the teleport gun which allows you to send a beam to any wall that will teleport you there once it reaches its destination. As that mechanic alone would soon run out of challenging situations, blue, red and green beams will make puzzles more difficult, as red beams will block your teleportation beam, blue beams will stop the gun's beam at their location, and green beams will send it upwards. Combing those simple mechanics with the machine gun that will allow you to shoot enemies in your path in addition to using the teleport gun creates situations that are challenging, yet fun to solve and think your way out of. Secrets are also an important part of the experience, as exploration is rewarded with items such as health upgrades or the machine gun upgrade that allows you to shoot faster, and looking for different alternatives out of a certain screen will often take you to a completely new one with a new challenge ahead. The most important thing is that the game allows you to play however you want to, as you can avoid shooting enemies completely, making your way forward using the teleport gun alone, or take your time, explore the world around you and make sure you collect everything along the way.Rating: 8GraphicsOut There Somewhere goes for an old school look, with simple, low resolution textures formed out of squares, and while that art style fits the concept of the game fairly well, the problem comes in the form of repetition using those textures, as each screen will look similar to the previous one, and even when you do reach an area that's meant to feel and look different such as Grigori's Tower, it still feels like the same square with a different color shade on top.Rating: 6.5AudioThe audio quality is pretty cheap, which isn't necessarily a problem since there isn't much to hear aside from the effects that will only show up when you command them to. The soundtrack is okay for this time of game, but it does get boring pretty quickly, but since there isn't much else to hear aside from the background song, you could just mute it and play your own tunes.Rating: 5.5ExtrasIt will probably take you around one hour to complete Out There Somewhere for the first time, but just as a note the game can be completed in less than 15 minutes, and the game even encourages you to do that as it has a specific achievement. You could play it a second time to earn all the achievements and see the secret areas you might have missed, but afterwards that's it.Rating: 6VerdictOut There Somewhere is a cute, challenging adventure to spend your afternoon with, as long as you don't mind the fact that it will be over fairly soon, but for its low price and a possible secondary replay, it's worth a try.Rating Overall: 6.6Check out the full review and a lot more about Out There Somewhere at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=357

Posted: September 17, 2016
												Out There Somewhere is a simple as well as simply priced game on Steam with a lots of detail added in such a short little space adventure.  While it is short in stature, it makes up for it with the quality put into the the low price, sprite-work, and the gameplay.  The game itself costs two dollars on Steam, so it is very unlikely you will regret your purchase with all of the fibers of your wallet if you dislike it, unless of course those two dollars were needed to save you from dying of hunger. Of course, there is a chance one might receive a coupon for it upon crafting a badge or something, further decreasing the affordable price.  The sprites give off a very solid Metroid reminiscence, which is fair because the game was reportedly inspired by Super Metroid.  Each of the environments are tailored almost exclusively with each screen that your character passes through.  They may have an underlying theme to it all, be it uncharted wasteland to menacing metal, but they all have something unique in level design incorporated within the game.  The game is built around a teleportation mechanic.   A specially designed gun fires a blue bullet that, upon impact with any solid platform, teleports you to that specific location.  The gameplay revolves around you, and how you determine when to fire, not to mention time how long the bullet takes to reach your designated location.  Of course, with all of those pluses, the game itself is rather short.  If you do not go out of your way to find any collectables, (and even if you do) the game boils down to a solid hour or two of total playtime.  Which is a shame, because the teleport gun mechanic is rather fun to play around with.  Another issue I have with the game is the way the levels are organized.  I feel as though game is very linear, each level designed to be a simple obstacle that prevents you from proceeding, so any unique level concepts are used once and left behind.  If one wanted to find the collectables aforementioned, they would have to backtrack through each of the levels that appeared to be designed in mind for separate challenges meant simply for providing something to hop through once and be done with, compared to games like the original Metroid or its remake, Zero Mission where there are several tunnels connected in a sense where you can be familiar with the layout and return without it feeling like you have to return through a single linear stretch.  However, the game is a solid buy through and through.  If you feel like adventuring on an alien planet with a trusty teleportation machine, feel free to buy for a short yet sweet playthrough.

I finished it in about an hour, but i enjoyed it. It's not brutaly easy but it's quite forgiving, which could be a good thing if you rage easily.I don't know why you're not playing this game. It's mix of puzzles and platforming requires some skill and feels rewarding. I'll admit that it doesn't look like a winner just by looking at the trailer & screenshots, but it's solid.Yes, recommended.

Posted: August 15, 2016
												Graphics - 9/10, fit this game 100% perfectly. It is pleasing to look at but it can be too dark even with your brightness all the way up. If they just did a lighting overhaul it would go a long way.Story - 6/10, there isn't really a whole lot of story to this game. Basically you are on a space ship when aliens attack it, so naturally you go and fight them. You are overwhelmed and crash into an alien planet. You need to find a power core to get of the planet. During the game you hear from a few different NPC's that Grigori is a monster and they wish he wasn’t around, you also hear also hear he has that power core you need. So you take off on a mission to kill Grigori and get the power core.Gameplay - 9/10, while I want to say that this game has perfect gameplay, I can't. I personally feel that the beginning and ending space battles are unnecessary; I feel these two scenes are completely different from the rest of the game. Every other part of the game is plat-forming genius but then you have these button mashing sequences basically.Soundtrack - 8/10, I like the soundtrack this game has but I prefer to listen to my own music while I play because I'm personally not a huge fan of the "Classic Pixel Style" this game uses. But I do recognize that this a very well done soundtrack and I consider it worth having in my iTunes library.Overall - 32/40, even though I only have a short amount of time on this game as I am writing this (Currently 8 hours or so) I plan to add a lot more because I love this game. It is really addictive and I really recommend you buy it. I think it's worth full price but I imagine quite a few people would want to buy it when its on sale because it is so short.

Posted: November 29, 2015
												Out There Somewhere is an absolutely charming platformer that I highly recommend as an essential addition to any Steam user's library.  Much like Shovel Knight or Momodora, this is a modern game that looks and plays like one of the classics.The game's hero is a fighter pilot who is shot down during an epic space battle.  After crash-landing on a volcanic planet populated with friendly talking snails and strange tree-men, he ventures off, armed with a teleportation gun, to repair the ship and rejoin the battle.  Along the way, there's a few health upgrades and maybe even a weapon or two to help survive the baddies; there's also 11 hidden ship upgrades to find.While the platforming elements and the game's retro aesthetic are both great, the real star of the show is the teleportation mechanic.  Your primary trigger fires a slow-moving bolt of energy that instantly transports your character to the point of contact when a surface is struck.  Using this competently is necessary for getting through the game.  The really exciting bit, though, is the teleportation gun conserves momentum, just like Portal; beginning a leap just before your energy bolt hits something, for instance, means you'll still be traveling upwards after being teleported.  Mastering this makes for very satisfying gameplay, and abusing this mechanic to go as high or as far as you possibly can also lead you to secret areas or shortcuts that you wouldn't otherwise find. This game isn't very long, and while it's not a total cakewalk, the level of challenge is relatively low.  My first playthrough took about 90 minutes, and that was with a lot of optional exploration and puzzle-solving.  My second playthrough was a 100% playthrough, and took a little over an hour.  After learning the game's layout and mechanics, a speedrun will take not much more than 15 minutes.However, while not long, this game is really quite fun, and totally worth the very reasonable asking price.  Give it a shot, you won't regret it.

Posted: September 1, 2015
 SPOILER ALERT	I feel like that game is really worth the price... best spent 19 cents on a game. The Story	Humanity is in peril, Allies receives a signal that the notorious villain Grigori is attacking again and decide to call Yuri - our hero for help.As he sets out to fight Grigori, his ship gets destroyed and he sees Grigori landing on an unknown planet and he decides to follow him without any other choice since he crashes on the planet.As soon as our hero lands he sees that Grigori has imprisoned the intelligent life on this planet.          He must free the planet's citizens, find a power source to get his ship to work again and defeat Grigori for good. Gameplay	The game revolves mostly around teleporting which is done via your teleporting gun (It's nothing like portal's portal gun).You get teleported the moment your bullet hits a wall and you depending on your timing you can jump after teleporting which can help you reach otherwise unreachable locations and it makes up for really clever platforming.The movement and shooting once you obtain your Gauss gun really remind me of Cave Story which is a good thing.You can also collect 3 Alien artifacts with each one making you more durable to damage. Pros.	+Great pixelated art                 +Great music                                +Alot of replay value+Memorable protagonist+Fluid Gameplay.+Alot of secret collectibles. Cons.	-Really short Final Verdict   9.6/10

Posted: July 10, 2015
												Out There Somewhere is a neat little 2D Game. You can compare the design to the Metroid games and all in all the game structure really reminds me of "You Have To Win The Game", what is, by the way, a really nice game.A short assessment by myself:Story: 8/10   It is the classical "Hero-Kills-Evil" concept as it is in Megaman. Yuri is Megaman and Gregori is Dr. Wily.Soundtrack: 100/10 The soundtrack fits perfect and is just genius.Level Design: 10/10  It reminds of Metroid as I mentioned before.Controls: 5/10 The control is the only thing I want to criticize. I highly recommend to play this game with  a Game Pad, because it is a little bit awkward with the keyboard. (Compareable to "Super Meat Boy" + Keyboard" just worse...!)Difficulty: 10/10 Although you cannot adjust the difficulty in the game options you are able to play this game without getting frustrated. There are maybe some points where it can take a minute longer than usual but all in all the game is quiet easy.But it gets much more difficult when you try to find all cores or try to collect all steam achievements.

												Great little game.  Reminded me a lot of La Mulana (to a degree), VVVVVV (to a degree), Knytt Underground (to a degree). 												I got it only because the cards, and it was on 90% sale. I usually don't like platformers. Posted: August 15, 2016
												Graphics - 9/10, fit this game 100% perfectly. It is pleasing to look at but it can be too dark even with your brightness all the way up. If they just did a lighting overhaul it would go a long way.Story - 6/10, there isn't really a whole lot of story to this game. Basically you are on a space ship when aliens attack it, so naturally you go and fight them. You are overwhelmed and crash into an alien planet. You need to find a power core to get of the planet. During the game you hear from a few different NPC's that Grigori is a monster and they wish he wasn’t around, you also hear also hear he has that power core you need. So you take off on a mission to kill Grigori and get the power core.Gameplay - 9/10, while I want to say that this game has perfect gameplay, I can't. I personally feel that the beginning and ending space battles are unnecessary; I feel these two scenes are completely different from the rest of the game. Every other part of the game is plat-forming genius but then you have these button mashing sequences basically.Soundtrack - 8/10, I like the soundtrack this game has but I prefer to listen to my own music while I play because I'm personally not a huge fan of the "Classic Pixel Style" this game uses. But I do recognize that this a very well done soundtrack and I consider it worth having in my iTunes library.Overall - 32/40, even though I only have a short amount of time on this game as I am writing this (Currently 8 hours or so) I plan to add a lot more because I love this game. It is really addictive and I really recommend you buy it. I think it's worth full price but I imagine quite a few people would want to buy it when its on sale because it is so short.

Posted: September 11, 2016
												tl;dr A one-hour well-designed Portal-based platformer.Pros:  * Sort of like a 2D Portal, but with a Metroid vibe  * Clever and challenging level design - the kind that makes you feel clever for solving it  * Great retro-style soundtrack and visuals  * Character design is very "90s" - simple, clear, concise, and not trying too hard to be funny/cute/anythingCons:  * Keyboard support is clearly hacked on. Can't even map spacebar to jump.  * Combat is repetitive and feels like an afterthought  * Incredibly short, ~1hr.

												Not bad, but not memorable. The teleporting mechanic itself is unique, but the overall game feels all too familiar for those who played many puzzle-platformers. If you haven't played a lot of games from this genre, it may seem all new and exciting to you, but there are gems out there, somewhere, that deserve more your attention; if you are a veteran, I recommand it if you can never get enough of this kind of game. I had a fun ride, but I will probably forget this game in a few weeks, especially since it's so short. I gave a positive review because I had a nice experience, but I would give a neutral review if possible since you have to consider everything above to determine whether or not it's worth it.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												The game is quite interesting i have to say! - it really reminds me from a different game - i can't come up with the name for now - maybe later.However it still plays differently. you start with a ship - and it is some sort of "asteroids game"  - eventually you will lose and u will crash - - you have to find the missing parts of the ship. You have a teleport gun - if u shoot - there will be a projectile flying - which will let you teleport if hit to a wall. the game could be quite difficult too and with there puzzles. You also need intelligence and quick thinking in order to pass some area's.There are save stations/checkpoints throughout the level.It is also a little bit of "metroidvania" that u have to go back point to point to do somethimg. but so far i know - you do not have a map which COULD be dissappointingthe music is quite ok - it is 2D side scrolling 8 bit graphic style.monsters will respawn if u left the screen - the sound affects "from guns, exploding, deaths, etc" are a little bit cheap - i mean, its a very very old sound effect.You can play with an xbox controller. Which actually plays better then on keyboardDefault keyboard controls are weird. Z to teleport. X to jump. C to shoot. I think C should be jumping, Z to teleport and X to shoot.You can heal at checkpoints.THE GAME IS OK BUT SHORT! to make teleport useful - i do recommend using small hops, so that u can jump again once the projectile hit and u fly higher.I give this a 6/10

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												This game is very interesting.The story is about a space cop who is hunting a villain named Grigori. But after a fight with him, his space ship gets badly damaged and both land on a same planet. Main gameplay begins here and you have to find a light orb to fix your ship and defeat Grigori for good.Gameplay is really nice. you have a teleport gun which is frequently used in the game and nearly all of the puzzles must be solved with it and a gauss gun to kill enemies. After progressing further in the game, you will encounter new enemies, three types of lightbeams, mirrors, breakable objects and moving platforms which add to the challenge.PROS:- Nice gameplay- Great soundtrack- Collectables affect how much hard the last fight will be- Can 100% the game easily with a little skill and patienceCONS:- Short (Can be completed in 14 mins to 75 mins on first playthrough)- You HAVE to lose in the first encounter with Grigori and you can even lose at the beginning; but it's not clear. So you do your best to take him down and after a lot of minutes you find out it was a complete waste of time.- Some rare achivement problems: One of the achievement did not unlock until I did it's required action for the third time.VERDICT:This game is really nice and definitely worths trying but it's short and after you unlock every achievement, you may not want to play it anymore.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												Out There Somewhere is a platformer/puzzle game with bullet hell stages, with mechanics that resemble Portal.It's a very fun little game that, despite being very short (~2-3h of gameplay, maybe 4 if you want all achievements) is very entertaining and will keep you stuck to the computer until you beat it.PROS: Beautiful pixel graphics Funny and simple storyline Very rewarding to figure out how to pass certain levelsCONS: Short Game Storyline is not too deep, you won't get very attached to the characters Those who do not enjoy Bullet Hell (or are bad at it) will suffer at a couple points I died so many times at the final boss it gives me nightmares til todayFinal Score: 4/5Very fun little game, extremely worth its price tag. Highly recommend anyone who enjoys platformers/puzzle games to grab this. Sell some items or cards on the Market and grab it. It's totally worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												This is a short but excellent puzzle platforming adventure. It takes about the length of time a "chapter" might take in a longer game, so somewhere in the ballpark of an hour if you're going at a relaxed, casual pace. (There is an achievement for 20-minute completion for speedrunners.)Figuring out how to use the teleportation gun to solve each room---as well as discover secrets for the more observant---is very satisfying both to solve and to execute.There isn't much of a story here, but I don't think you'll care about that too much. What the game lacks in story, it makes up for in charm and style. It definitely has that nice Cave Story / Metroid kinda vibe that SNES era kids will love.I also got it on sale for NINETEEN CENTS?! That is a f***ing steal.

												I found Out There Somewhere to be very boring. Beyond the puzzle solving this game does almost nothing to pull you in. The puzzles are decent, requiring quick reactions. The teleportation gun is an interesting mechanic, and has a lot of potential, but I just don't care enough to go slogging through the rest of the game to get to this theoretical point of interest.The story may as well not be there, as it does nothing to intrigue the player beyond giving a background to the puzzles to come.I don't recommend this game unless you have a keen interest in 2d puzzle platformers, as well as a lack of interest in compelling story telling.

content:
Posted: January 11
Out there somewhere is a very cheap platformer game, and in this case you get nothing more than what you paid for. A bland, uninspired jumpfest. The game consists of you having to perform tricky jump after tricky jump until the end credits roll. Out there somewhere claims to be "Inspired by Cave Story, Super Metroid, and Portal," I don't see it - at all. I'd call it a lie in an attempt to boost sales, but there's nothing wrong with saying what inspired you, I guess. A satanic death metal band could claim the inspiration for their latest album was the Beatles' white album, even though you'd never actually hear that influence in any of their music.Apparently, if you're good at this sort of game, you'll finish Out there somewhere in less than an hour and are entitled to some bragging, for example in the form of the Steam Achievement for finishing the game. If you're not particularly good at this sort of game, you'll notice they managed to make 'Out there somewhere' very challenging (difficult) but forgot to add any fun or wonder to the gameplay, which would motivate to try and finish it anyway.All in all, Out there somewhere  is a below average platformer that's only for the die-hard platformer gamer who's looking for a quick but extremely difficult fix.

content:
Posted: January 1
												(Review writed with 7.6 hours gaming and all achievements unlocked - Jan 01st, 2017).Out There Somewhere is a 8-bit portal game with a little of space invaders. You play with a space pilot who's crashlanded on an alien world, and you've found yourself inside a retro-tinged platformer in which each room works as a single puzzle, all to repair your spaceship. Pros:- Challenging puzzles;- Nice 8-bit portal game play.Cons:	- Few levels;- Lame history;- Few boring challenges;- Hard achievements.6,0/10.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												Out There Somewhere is a clever game that's just all around quite humble and enjoyable to play. The platforming handles well, there's little secret areas throughout that still feel rewarding to find yet aren't too impossibly hidden, and it's got a short and sweet story. Game runs a little short (only took a few hours to 100% all the achievements), but the satisfaction from finishing the game justifies the price.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												Very nice platformer with an interesting game mechanic.You play as a captain of a space ship who ends up in a fight with a villain named Grigori (who is still out there somewhere btw)It result in your ship crashing on some alien planet. Now you have to find your way through the planet to get a light orb to fix your spaceship (Every spaceship needs light orbs cause you know... reasons...) and optionally collecting "abandoned cores". You have a teleport gun which teleports you to where the shot lands... a cool game mechanic that is very well implemented.Pros:-Figuring out how to get to the end of every screen is a lot of fun.-Timing and thought required make it enjoyable.-Short but not too short.-Tight controls.-Good soundtrack.-Good-looking pixel graphics.Cons:-Almost no story. (doesn't really matter for this kind of game ... use your Imagination)Highly Recommended!

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												MINOR SPOILERS FOLLOWThis game isn't long, but that doesn't matter, because it is a well-constructed game.  Initially, you begin with a side-scrolling space-shooter sequence that takes you through an army of rival space ships.  After the initial boss fight (which you are supposed to lose), you begin exploring a planet armed initially with only a portal gun.  You'll find an actual weapon later on to fight enemies with and to help with solving puzzles.The game is basically an action-platformer in the vein of games like Metroid with its exploration for various items, including extenders to your life meter and components which can power-up your repaired ship at the end of the game.  There aren't a whole lot of mechanics to the game, which is fitting for its short length.  This also makes the game easy to pick up and play.  There is a good challenge to the later sections, but there is nothing that truly feels overwhelming or unfair, which is a testament to the overall game design.  The price is fair as there is replayability to earn achievements.  For such a short title, there is a fairly large number to attain, and I can see people earning all of them with lots of practice.I can find very little to criticize about this game.  You do have to be careful of scene switches because you can walk and/or jump into a hazard without fully realizing it, similar to Castle in the Darkness, though not nearly as unfair as in the latter title.  Also, in some of the vertical sections, I had to stop and search for my character, who was just about as far down the screen as possible, usually in a corner!  A brief, flashing arrow pointing to your character would help here, but this is not a big criticism.  It's possible to solve every room on the first try if you're observant and careful; I can even see a few people maybe having a deathless run on the first playthrough.Out There Somewhere has just the right length for casual gamers while being robust enough for those looking for a challenge, especially those seeking to 100% the game through both winning and through completing the achievements.  I highly recommend this game.  It is both well-crafted and extremely well balanced.  Buy it!9.0 / 10

												This game was so promising, and I sat down expecting a sweet metroidvania style platform puzzler. I played it for 30 minutes, and took a break to get some food. Then I sat down again and realized I was just outside the chamber of the first boss. "Great", I thought, a boss battle is always nice. So I went ahead and defeated the boss in about five minutes. Then the game ended... WHAT!? 35 minutes of gameplay, and ONE boss? Really?I realize this game is only 5€, and you can't expect much from a game that cheap, but still, 35 minutes of content just isn't enough for me to recommend this game.If you still need to kill half an hour and like platform puzzlers with a wee bit of skill needed, then by all means, this game is for you.

												I normally try to make well-written reviews, but due to this game's slow performance I'm not even able to play it.I got it on a sale really cheap, so I don't really mind wasting a couple coins in it, but the hardware requirements this game has written are totally false, my computer meets them but the game still runs horribly slow.The worse part is that the game doesn't even have complex graphics, I'm able to run games like OpenArena, Minecraft and other games at 60 FPS at some points, this games goes like at 5 FPS and the graphics are just horrible simple.Also, the game lacks options to disable graphic effects or anything else, the only graphic option is to toggle fullscreen.

I learned this after another 5 minutes of mashing the fire button and dodging attacks.  I didn't even get to the real game, and now I don't even want to.Devs, if you want to blow up my ship, that's fine.  Make it a scripted event, or give the enemy an unavoidable attack.  Don't waste my time, and don't make me do something that feels stupid.  Having to intentionally destroy my ship completely breaks immersion and removes all my motivation for continuing.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Inititally, upon starting Out There Somewhere, I was skeptical. Another pixel art puzzle platformer. But the game started to grow on me, the art style was pleasant, and the music is surprisngly well done. The mechanics of the game are simple, but fun and intuitive. The gameplay revolves around a gun which, when fired, fires a bolt which you teleport to when it collides with something. The puzzles designed around this are quite clever, and the game introduces more puzzle mechanics that spice up an already interesting style. It was getting interesting. And just as I felt as though the game was going to advance into something better, it ended. Now, I purchased this game for twenty cents, but it runs for five dollars normally. And because of this, I ultimately cannot recommend Out There Somewhere, as the game time is abyssmally short for the asking price, and honestly left me dissatisfied. I was able to beat the game in under an hour and a half. That sucks. The gameplay itself is enjoyable, but it feels more like a Flash game in the end.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												It really hurts me to not recommend this game...Because when you look at it, it is very pretty, the gameplay is smooth, and all the art design (atmosphere, sounds, story...) is very nice and thought.But... it is much too short, and quite unsatisfying in terms of experience. It is definitely a flaw in games these years, although some others would argue it is a plus. Yet for me, such a small contribution in terms of entertainment and gaming is exactly like with toys and games... a diminished version, a raw skeleton without any flesh or organs.In other words? The type of gamer I am can not feel fully satisfied with what feels like a demo, like a "short story" of a gameplay mechanic. Please realize I am not asking for a 100hours long rpg, but this "little gamish piece of art" would have been great if there was more substance to it, more body. As is, I feel sorry to say that I can not recommend it...

content:

												This game makes much of being inspired by Portal. But they missed one of the most important parts of Portal's design. This game deliberately punishes you for mistakes. Instead of making recovery quick and painless, expect to grind out the same moments of levels over and over to get back to where you fell last time. Interesting game, interesting mechanics, wastes too much of my time.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												Playing on a Mac here, if that makes any difference.I'm sure it would be fun if my controls worked half of the time I played the game. The first time I launched it, the escape button didnt work, so i coulnt bring up the menu, but i troopered through. Once I completed the Galaga section, I landed on the planet. No story text popped up, no hints, nothing. "Okay, maybe there's not supposed to be anything here." I play around with the controls and learn them, since my escape button doesnt work. Controls learned, time to move on. I go to the right, since nothing is blocking my way, and nothing happens. Screen doesnt change to the next area or anything. "This is really, really weird. Let me restart the game." Alright, restarted the game and it puts me on the planet, just after Galaga. I get story text and hints this time, and my escape button works! Awesome. I move right, and then the screen changes. Fantastic! Game is going good...until I have to shoot my teleport gun. "What the heck?" I press X multiple times and no response. "Dangit. Gotta restart again." Restart game, game works in all aspects. Gameplay was alright, I guess. I think it tried to be too much like Risk of Rain, a game I highly reccomend, in both the controls and the overall feel of the game.  But for the technical problems I had, I cant reccomend Out There Somewhere.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												Out There Somewhere is not a great Steam game, but would be right at home on a Flash website.The opening feels like a student's first Multimedia Fusion game after following a tutorial on how to make a space shooter.  Staticky sound effects, zero enemy variety, unnatural parallax scrolling, no interesting visual effects... It's pretty amateurish and gave me a poor first impression.As the game progressed, I was pleased that it has some originality, and it's reasonably satisfying to jump around and teleport from place to place.  In the game's cleverer moments, it does a good job introducing new mechanics and ideas.It was over in less than an hour.  I was expecting the game to go on for quite a bit longer, considering it hadn't expanded upon the teleport-gun mechanic all that much, and I was still seeing the same three enemies.  I never spent a full five minutes in any one room, and I know that because several of the Steam achievements I didn't get reward being slow.  I'm sure there were some areas that I missed out on, but I don't care to go back to them, because it would mean going back through the unchallenging samey puzzles I already solved.I couldn't tell you what the plot of the game was, or how any of the music goes from memory, because none of it particularly stood out.  What I do remember is how irritating it was that the gun fired shots so slowly, and how enemies seemed to take more hits than necessary.  I remember discovering all the doors are needlessly one-way when I tried to check an earlier room and couldn't do it.  And I remember how closing a textbox had an awkward delayed reaction because I kept immediately reopening NPC dialog on accident.The way I see it, Out There Somewhere feels more like a prototype than a finished game.  There's very little diversity, no thought required, not enough polish, and even the visuals feel flat and artificial.  It's not bad, per se, but it's not great, and not something I'd recommend to my friends if they had to pay money for it.

												A really neat little platformer that takes about 100 mins to complete the story of on my first go. As far as i can tell to 100% it you would also have to play a number of the levels in reverse as well to get all the collectable which i havent done. The main mechanic of this game is the teleportation system which is really cool, it allows for some really interesting puzzles that may require you to think about for a bit before you can complete them. In the same way Portal requires you to think with portals, this game requires you to think with perfectly timed teleportation. Would reccomend it at the normal price. So if its at 15p it totally worth it.

												A cute little platformer that reminds me of a 2D Portal. There's a lot going on here for the price. The game has a nice ramping difficulty, but none of the puzzles get so insane you won't be able to solve them. The soundtrack is awesome, and the artstyle is new-age retro, which is definitely up my alley. The combat (while not a major focus of the game) feels a little clunky, and there are some sections that seem like filler (not intutive level design) but a solid game overall.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Let me start out by saying this: There's no way I can do this game justice by a simple review.Good retro visuals, a good, catchy and well made soundtrack, perfectly responsive controls, a good and simple story, and high replayability are only a few of this game's qualities. Drawing clear inspiration from Pixel's work (Cave Story and its successors), Out There Somewhere manages to dish out the right amount of nostalgia, while being unique enough to earn its own place in Indie game history.The first playthrough will take about one hour, but with so many hidden secrets and alternate ways to complete the puzzles, I can almost guarantee you'll start a new game at least two more times.Truth be told, I've written and deleted at least three paragraphs trying to describe this game, and I still can't do it. My recomendation is simple: buy it and see for yourself.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												Disappointing. Being on-boarded to a game with a spammy splash-screen is NOT a good indication of things to come. The actual mechanic was interesting and accessable, though I--a not-great player of games--finished in about an hour. I was narrating while playing, too, and demonstrating, so actual gameplay is probably closer to 45 minutes for a good player. I probably won't go back and 100% the achievements. It's just not worth it to me, so that is telling.Is this game worth it on sale? Yes. Is this game worth it full price? Not for me, but probably for most people. Just bear in mind that you're paying for around an hour's worth of entertainment, and this is a one-shot deal as there is no procedural generation at work here.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												Platformer= Anger, sure I get it. :(  Warning: You'll need to watch a walkthrough or find a forum post  I've gotten stuck twice. Which isn't bad in itsef. The first time I was given a hint I didn't read, my bad. The second time on "mirror wall" there's no real hint on how to get past the puzzle. Finding the forum post get's harder with a title like "mirror wall", and finding a youtube video is even worse, as you have to watch like minutes to an hour to find the part you are stuck on.  :(    ControlsOn my Xbox controller there's a little lagg. This doesn't help with the precision the game requires. I have to wait .25 to jump. When preforming a teleport jump, I have to time this, I died a lot until I got the timing right. :) Basic gameplay Smooth, when working. The teleport gun works. Shooting and teleporting are very amazing. :) Level DesignIt's an amazing world. :) ArtThe reasson I bought this game. It's amazing. From enviroment to character, it's really some great pixel art work. Get it on sale. I did.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												Well, the first thing that met me when I started the game was a screen that wanted me to fill in an email address to get a 'free game', and the launch screen for Out There Somewhere didn't even start before I submitted an address. Then my antivirus gave an alarm about identity theft. After I let the antivirus fix the problem, the game itself finally started.The game itself is kinda nice, with innovative mechanics, but anyone trying to play this without some anti virus protection installed is probably royally screwed. Hence, I really, REALLY can't recommend it.An hour after I stopped playing it, the anti virus went off again. The game still tries to do something illegal in the background.Well, at least I got it for 0.02 euro.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												A short, but entertaining retro puzzle platformer.Actually it has retro graphic, which I dislike, but the fun gameplay mechanic - jumping, shooting, teleporting to solve puzzles make up for it. The gameplay basically is a platformer where you have to go through multiple rooms containing threats like aliens and lavas by utilizing your teleport gun and pistol. Some thinking and some fasthand are required, though it's not frustrating or hard like Super Meat Boy.Chiptune music is cheesy, but it's alright.It's in-arguably a bit short, though. Some people even have beaten the game in ten minutes or so, I did it in one hour. Well, forgive me. Game runs fine in my toaster laptop, 60 FPS straight.Controller support sucks, but at least I can remap my Dinput based controller F310 Logitech. It also has Steam Achievements (incentives for people who want to replay the game) and Trading Cards, good value overall.96% off at the moment - 0.20 USD equivalent, well worth every penny.Definitely recommended.

With all of the nonsense getting through greenlight recently, it is nice to see an intelligent platformer that tests both your mind and dexterity skills, whilst managing a simple 'find the engine part' scenario after getting trapped on an unknown planet.  Things are kept nice and easy to begin with, but soon become more challenging as the game progresses.  Platforming is the genre type and the game benefits from responsive controls, good collision detection and audio feedback.Graphically - Nothing brilliant, but a competent throwback to the 8/16-bit days of the 90'sSound - Simple effects.  Nothing obnoxious - Once again, 8-bit styled around the PC engine eraDo I recommend?  I bought this for 19p on a sale and I have to tell you, it was a steal!  If you can get it for around £1 ($1.70) or less, you'll have a great little budget gem worthy of any retro-style platforming fan out there

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												This game is for those interested in speedrunning, looking at what your indie project could become, or a literal example of many game design teachings that stick out like a sore thumb. I would say that this game has its moments, but really, the game does nothing much to make itself have moments of impact.It's a metroidvania game that lacks bosses, powerups, or smart puzzles that offer diversity over difficulty. You'll get tired of it unless you enjoy games like the Witness for its puzzles alone. There's no climax other than getting minor upgrades or entering your ship for the final boss. There's no control of pacing aside from locking off features to your character. A new game+ mode would've really helped, where it lets you explore the game world past the final boss considering how the map makes a complete circuit but the game decides to be far too linear, and for that I think it fails.It's a short combination of megaman and portal without the gripping soundtrack, hardcore gameplay, or unique narrative. If you're a sucker for gameplay that doesn't dip in quality, then sure, pick this game up for the dollar (or 25 cents) it's worth. You get it's full worth for what you pay. It's a short, but mildly sweet experience. It's got cute character designs, neat gameplay designs, but when it comes to anything more than puzzle solving and waiting for monster cycles, it falls short. On the plus side, it's short, and easy to speedrun with the in-game timer mechanic.As far as minimally priced games go, this is one of the better ones, but you could always save up your money for a fantastic 10 dollar game over the short-lived "experience" of this one.

content:
Posted: March 14
												One of the best "Cheapest games" I've ever played. Out There Somewhere is an underrated game that's not heard of often and people will look at games such as Out There Somewhere and say something along the lines of: "This game looks cheap and the price is cheap so it will be a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game" But thats not the case with this game and I was proved wrong. I bought this game under 20p (So that will be something like 30-40 bucks worth) and the game was pretty decent! They did a good job with handling the platformer, retro and puzzles, in a way it made me feel nostalgic.Pros:It has a good amount of content for a game thats under a pound/dollar.The puzzles are a bit thought-provoking but are fairly alright once you know what to doHas good level designs Has a nice soundtrack to it (Love some 8-bit or 16-bit feel or whatever bit it is)Nice artwork Some good enjoyment out of the game (Especially for those who like retro feel, puzzle and sci-fi setting types)Boss fights have a Mega Man type of feel to themNice sound effectsSteam Trading Cards Cons: The ending of the game is predictableThe story is alright at best but it's a basic sort of story Wanted more but again it's a cheap made game that prices itself for under a pound/dollar so I understand thatIf I had to rate this game on a scale out of 1/10 it would be 6/10 I recommend it despite the score I gave it but that's understandable.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
Inventive unpretentious 2D platformer6/10 ★★★★★★☆☆☆☆Let's make 2 things clear - I do not fancy platform games (I am not a six-year-old) and I do not long for pixel art graphics (an insult to my GPU). Having said so, Out There Somewhere is both and I can't stop enjoying this game.Gameplay seemlessly joins skills and wits, thanks to one simple, but innovative machanics.This blends nicely to the world and the story, and turns the game into an unpretentious and surprisingly coherent adventure.Graphics is simple but ejoyable pixel art, fitting the the game idea. Audio is ok. This is a bugdet product and does not bring visual fireworks. And thanks to the great mechanics does not need any.Out There Somewhere came to me as a surprise. I did not expect much and, boy, how wasn't I prepared for so much fun!.Summing upWell-executed platformer with inventive gameplaypositive good idea for gameplay, well developed into mechanics good, upretentious execution good, pixel-art graphicsnegative just a 2D platformer  ¯\_(ツ)_/¯A little, budget gem. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												Speedrunner with a teleport jumping difficulty curve.(i'm not a big fan of this genre of gaming, so go easy on me. don't take this review to heart)This game goes from simple to annoyingly jumbled with little to no help along the way. Expect to be confused and a little frustrated from the beginning. I think that a more helpful tutorial should of been in place, especially for newer players and people who aren't familiar with speedrunners.Most of the levels are really easy, but a few in between are just plain hard, from jumping and teleporting with miliseconds of error to jumping and dodging enemies while firing teleport shots across the map, it ramps up really fast. You also have to repeat a lot of content if you mess up, which is often due to the quick timing required.Easy game to play, difficult to master.The game is really short, only lasting around 2-3 hours. The game is only 1$. Anyway, this is my short review on this game, I didn't like it but I had to give it a try. I hope this review does not upset you, it is simply my opinion.Personal Rating: 1/5

												Uh, are you kidding me? 1 hour of gameplay? Really?! I'm glad I didn't spend a whole lot on this one. To the designer's credit, the game was incredibly fun, despite being incredibly short and linear. The teleportation and platforming puzzles were excellent. The retro cut scenes were hilarious. However, I was hoping that when they said "inspired by Metroid" they'd actually have some Metroid-esque RPG elements. No such luck I'm afraid. If you can get this title for less than a dollar, I'd say go for it. At least you get steam cards and an hour of fun. Otherwise, this is a hard pass.

												Controls are too weird, cant swap to wasd so i have to use arrows, i cant use the mouse, but even so, its too awkward to use only the keyboard. this is a controller game only, i dont even see why they enabled keyboard support.the game starts off ok, and there are weird "puzzles" but UGH THE CONTROLS FOR KEYBOARD, i was struggling on every puzzle because x and z are not my prefferd jump and shoot buttons, i prefer space to be sump and x for shoot, or mouse. there is an option to change controls, space is not able to be used, mouse buttons arent able to be used. i give this game a 2/5, there is work put into it, i can at least see that, but the controls are horrid, not only that, but the volume control is horrindus as well, i mark of 2 stars for that, and 1 star for no immediate backstory, from what i can tell, you're a spacecop and you gotta fight to protect your mother planet, there is no story as to why or anything so........

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												I'd love to be able to recommend this game as it looks really fun but can't from my own personal experience. My experience is it's not possible to actually play it. I emailed the developers a couple months ago asking for help but haven't heard a thing from them.The problem is that the controls don't work using gamepad or keyboard & mouse. Once the start screen has loaded up, it's like there is a stuck key for pressing left and also up and down are reversed. So after eventually getting the game to load, your character immediately goes left and thats it ! the level is supposed to progress to the right so that screws that up, 2-3 seconds of seeing a sprite move to the left of a level isn't a good game in my books.I have googled the problem and searched forums but found nothing to help. So I'd avoid this game as it will be a gamble paying anything for it.

content:
Posted: January 12
												If you go into this game thinking that it will be a Metroidvania game based off its description you will be dissappointed. It is extremely linear and can be beaten in under an hour on your first playthrough with no prior knowledge of the game. I was only stuck on one of the puzzles for a long time. Art style is alright but nothing to be shocked by, basic chibi pixel. The soundtrack only had a few songs in it and some of them were pretty good. If I had to tell you my favorite part of the game I would say it is the bullet-hell shooters. Unfornately these are short segements at the begining and end of the game. For 2 bucks it is a resonable price, however I could get better games for 2 bucks on a smart phone.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												If you want a way to blow a few bucks on a game that's less than 2 hours long this is pretty good. The game ends way too quickly and the concepts introduced are barely compounded upon in the late game. There is little story and just when it feels like the game is going to take off and start getting serious... it' over. It feels like an hour long tutorial to a more complicated game. The music isn't that great at all and it isn't really an "artistic" game either. It's a neat idea but there isn't any meat to this game at all. It feels like this game was thrown together real quick to make a quick buck.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												Pros:-Metroidvania with matching art style-Interesting teleporting mechanics with different beams that do different things-Starts difficult, which makes it reminiscent of older games and their difficulty-60FPS?-Good soundtrackCons:-Pits of death. EVERYWHERE. And they're so open that it's hard not to fall in them during a puzzle.-Vertical Platforming that, if you fail one part, you will fall down a screen back to nearly the beginning every time.-Actually, all the puzzles make you restart them in one way or another when you fail one part.-Soundtrack doesn't really match up with the mood of some situations-NPCs are borderline useless to talk to, despite you being consistently encouraged to talk to them-WAY too many tutorials. Every time you see a new beam, the game wants you to know what it is. Every time a pixel on a graphic is shaded differently, the game has to bring up a slow-moving dialogue box to tell you. LET ME FIGURE IT OUT.-Puzzle mechanics are interesting, but they get bland very quickly, so to remedy that something new appears every screen or so in the beginning. This, however, will make the game even more bland in the end because there's way too much involved into the game that it's too complicated and ends up being uninteresting anyways.-Every once in a while I get lag spikes for some reason. I'm running on an Intel i7-4500U with 8GB RAM on Windows 10 (Home Edition) 64-bit. There is absolutely no reason this game should have any lag spikes. Also why does it claim it requires 512MB VRAM on the store page? Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 Full Burst and Revolution require the same specs and is more graphically demanding in every way I can think of than this game. Also 1GB of RAM does seem like a lot to ask for with this sort of game Possibly unoptimized engine or code? I mean, I'm sure it can run on most machines decently, but if the developers here were working for a publisher for a larger-scale game, it would be unacceptable if they were to make the game require way more resources from the computer than it really should.Conclusion:Not really worth $1.99, you'd be better off paying around half of that for the game, or less.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Out There Somewhere claims to have been inspired by Cave Story and Super Metroid, but those games raise expectations in my mind that I feel the game did not meet. The game is far shorter than expected, my first playthrough lasting little more than an hour. It is also not nearly as varied as Cave Story and other Metroidvania-style games; you will spend the majority of the game with just your teleport gun and a normal gun. And while the puzzles involving the aforementioned teleport gun are definitely interesting, the claimed inspiritations led me to believe I would have a bigger arsenal at my disposal.Another issue I have with the game is the use of bullet hell-like portions of the game. These sections feel very out of place in a game that is otherwise essentially a 2D version of Portal.Out There Somewhere is a decent game, considering the price, but the tauted inspirations to me implied a set of standards that the game did not deliver. Like I said above, this is 2D Portal. If that is what you want, then this game will do. But if you're looking for something Metroidvania-esque, look elsewhere.

												This review is based on the first few levels, but already I'm impressed by the music and the 2D portal mechanics, which utilizes your teleport gun.The story consists of Captain Yuri, a generic anime space cop chasing a generic fugitive alien warlord (named Grigori for whatever odd reason) onto the surface of the planet that they have botch crash landed on. Noticed the typo did you? Yeah there are a few in the game as well. I'm going to get to why I changed my review from a positive to a negative by the end of the game, but first we have to look at the positives:Pros:Silly fun and cool acheivementsOutstanding music, seriously it's never annoyingClever easter eggs and referencesFun "2D Portal" platforming, yes there are a lot of portal copycats, but this one is done wellSounds great, right? How could I not like this game after saying all these nice things about it? Well here we go:Cons:The plot is recycled barf, not that I expected much from this type of game, however this particular execution of "You're the hero, he's the villian, go duke it out somewhere... IN SPACE" was tired at best, which doesn't lend itself to the story like a Metroid game, or hell, even Portal's story was better. "We're here to do research on portals, oh just kidding, I'm a sociopathic computer that has been trying to kill you this entire time!"This ultimately results in the one and only boss battle in the entire game. Did I mention this game was short? Yeah so with such a great game so far, guess what they went with for the boss battle, the one and only boss battle? How did JonTron put it again?Oh yes.Simon ♥♥♥♥ING says.Grigori goes from the left wall to the right every three times you hit him, and the only gun you have in the game you get in the second act (this game is not long enough to even have a third, mind you) and it's not a bazooka, it's a tiny little pea shooter that kills normal enemies in 4 hits, and Gregori needs half a bazillion to go down.Then Grigori decides it's time for round two in some spaceships that you've both miraculously had time to repair, and get this - during the game you were supposed to have picked up power ups you can only use in this one battle, but they are barely explained to you, and I don't think I picked up more than one. Oh what to do... Can't go back for them, so onwards you go for some more....SIMON ♥♥♥♥ING SAYS... BULLET HELL MODE.Yes, I ragequit that boss, yes, speedrunners have beaten this game in a clean 17 minutes...Maybe I'll go back and kill the dumb boss later...No, don't get it unless it's on sale, if for nothing else but the music, or just buy the soundtrack if it's available.Final verdict:3/10 - Cool (OK borrowed) concept and music with nice pixel visuals, but it all goes down the drain due to a tedious and unforgiving boss fight, and the lack of content or emotional investment/story development overall.

number of helpful: 9 of 23 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												I literally beat this game in 54 minutes. When I beat the first boss (the only boss) the credits rolled and I thought the developers were making a joke. This is probably the shortest game I have ever played, and I was greatly disappointed by that. This game describes itself as taking the pages out of Super Metroid and Cave Story, both very long games with enormous worlds to explore, but this game is nothing like them at all. It's a shame, because what is in the game is awesome. Everything is built just right and it's something new I've never encountered before. But, this game is virtually a tech demo of what should have been a much more expansive game. If the developers made a sequel to this I'd buy it in a heartbeat, but this game by itself just isn't long enough to merit a purchase at its listed retail price.

Posted: April 22, 2015
												This game is ok, but I have a few problems-1. The keys are so dumb. jump is z. Like what even. You can rebind them, but not to something sensible like up or space.2. The levels are repetetive. I'm already bored with the art style and level design3. The game brings nothing new. If you're looking for a retro platformer, look elsewhere. The classics are far better than this. Shovel knight did it right, but this has a lame story, dull characters, and nonexistanct plot.4. Did I mention that the levels are repetative?5. I beat the game in under an hour. I'm no speedrunner either. It's certainly not worth $5. You'd be better off playing some flash games.The soundtrack is pretty good though, but I mean, isn't that expected of modern retro games by now?tl;dr- Repetetive, frustrating, and terrible keybinding that you can't use up or space in. Brings nothing new to the genre.(I got this for 20 cents though so if its on sale get it then farm the cards :D

content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
												Out There Somewhere is a waste of time.  Everything about it is uninteresting.  The puzzles are never challenging and the teleportation mechanic is berely explored.  Most enemies can be ignored and killing them is a chore because the gun fires too slowly.  Instead of being engaging, each obstacle only serves to inconvenience you.  The colors are so same-y, all the envoronments blend together, and so dark it's sometimes unclear where enemies and platforms are.  The music is generic and the writing is boring and entirely unneccessary.  Things were only put in the game because games usually have them, not because they add anything to the experience.  All they add are a few seconds to the game's paltry length.Everything in this game has been done better in a thousand internet flash games.  Instead of spending money on this, go online and play one for free.

												Finished the game in just under 1h30m... It's way too short. I expected 4-5h of gameplay. Game mechanic is fun though. Way... Way too short. Posted: October 21, 2016
												The game is ridiculously difficult, even with a gamepad.Update:It turns out all i had to do was git gud. Once i figured out how to double jump, the game was a breeze. I even did a second, much quicker run of the game where i was able to get nearly all cores and artifacts, upgrade the ship, and defeat the bad guy, in 40 minutes or less.So... the game is actually pretty decent after all: cute graphics and music, and fairly interesting puzzles and secrets.By the way, the secret to double jumping is that the character must touch the floor and jump right before the teleportation. So, just time the jump to land before the pellet hits the wall, keep your eyes on it, and jump right before it hits.

Posted: November 5, 2015
												A fun little puzzle platformer, featuring 2d side scrolling with a teleport gun. (Think a portal gun, but only a 1-way 'port.) Pretty short if you blitz through, with the majority of game time being in exploration for all of the different collectibles. Very charming graphics and soundtrack. Story isn't terribly strong, but the gameplay is great enough to make up for it. Difficulty felt just right - difficult but not too punishing and not discouraging.Overall, a very fun experience. Would definitely recommend!

Posted: November 5, 2015
												A very unique and enjoyable platformer centered around using a teleport gun, almost like a 2D Portal. The puzzles are well-crafted and clever, with more than one way through many of them. The biggest downside for me was the length of the game or, more accurately, the lack thereof. This game is very short. The 1.6 hours I have on record was a single full playthrough, beginning to end. The only replay value is in the achievements, if you're into that sort of thing. If you're like me, and couldn't care less about the achievements, you may find yourself thankful that you got the game on sale and only paid $0.19 for it. I recommend the game - not the price. $5 is a little steep for a game that's over so quickly. What's there is worth playing, but it's not worth the asking price. Even with as challenging as some of the puzzles are, requiring multiple attempts, I managed to beat the game in 90 minutes - and I'm pretty terrible at platformers.Get it on sale, and you won't be disappointed. Pay full price, and you might find yourself a little irritated at the shortness of the game.

												I payed 21 cents for this game and got 81 minutes of fun out of it. I am sure for more skilled puzzle people it will take you probably 45 minutes to finish. It is a good one go game if you have 1 hour to play video games. It was fun and the ending was very repeatative and easily won once you his moves. The space battles were easy however the setup for playing on the planet could ahve been done better in my opinion. The story for the game was very good. The friendly aliens threw me off but aside from that they played a good part and also made you feel like a badass hero.All in all for the price I payed and also the brain teazers for certain levels I recommend this game for anyone wanting a fun and casual game that they want to draw out or just try to speed run.

I have played through it many times, trying to get all of the achievements.Note: The trailer is misleading because the space ship shooter minigame is only at the start and end for only like 1 minute.What is good about it: GREAT game mechanics, catchy music, funny (and slightly cheesy) characters, secrets that are fun to find, controller support and steam trading cards.What is bad about it: The controls took a while for me to get used to and the trailor.If you see this game on sale, don't hesitate to buy it.

												This game was a huge amount of fun. Everything about it feels very tight and responsive. The puzzles are all fair and challenging, very reminiscent of Portal. I finished it in a little under two hours, but for $0.19 I'd say it was definitely worth it. Even if I'd paid the full $4.99 price, I would still be happy with this purchase and game.

Posted: November 4, 2015
												Out There Somewhere is a nice platformer.  Solid controls, quick feedback, and some secret content.  There are about 3 enemies, including the final boss, who is a pain to beat.  This game is definetely one of those titles that makes you want to explode.This game, in total, took me 64 minutes to beat.  I did this in one sitting.It's a good platformer.  Not very rich in story, but solid gameplay.  Why not pick it up while it's on sale for $.19?

Posted: November 4, 2015
												I'm one of those rare idiots who did everything he could to beat the opening area, defiant of the 'no-win' sccenario. Trust me, let yourself get beaten. The real game starts the moment you fail.What plays out after you crash is one of the more charming retro indies this side of Steam. While not quite Portal, the puzzles revolving around the teleportation gun are fun and mind-bending. Some of the toughest ones are optional, but its a fair challenge throughout. A full run will cost you little more than 2 hours, but there is a lot of little things to stumble upon, and the game is worth playing through multiple times simply for the extra challenge, and the chance to see what you might've missed. On top of all this, there is an utterly lovely soundtrack with a great sound design over all. Rare is it that brevity can be counted in a game's favor, but Out There Somewhere knew when to take its leave. There is plenty of optional stuff to mess with too mind you, but for the cost of a chicken sandwich you can experience a truly remarkable little gem. One of the few games I truly wish I could give more money to.

Posted: September 6, 2015
												I won't lie.. I haven't played for long.. but from what I have played.. I really like this game and would recommend it to anyone who likes puzzle games, using your mind, and just generally having fun.. because this is what I've seen of the game! I bought a game costing a lot more and like it a lot less than Out There Somewhere. Don't let the graphics fool you.. it is fun.. the story line and thought process put into this game are good. Do yourself a favor.. get the game. I hope you have as much fun as I have had and I'm sure I have a ways to go before I finish but this is the kind of game that encourages (me anyway) to want to finish it.

Posted: September 7, 2015
												First off, I bought this game on a whim for when it was only 19 cents, because I had some spare money from the steam sale, and this looked like something that wasn't a ripoff of Minecraft, see 7 cent 'Uncrowded'.I played it through to completion, and though while the puzzles are phenomenal, using a set of mechanics that really support the platforming, and give a whole new spin on it by the end, there are somethings I dislike about this game, and will mention below.First off, all the tacked on mechanics, i.e. the space battles, which are the first and last things that happen in the game.  They're contrived, really have no point, and if the game ended with the final battle that tested your skills, then that would be amazing, not the 'This is my final form' bs.And second off, the story will rub you the wrong way.  It will.  I recommend skipping all the dialogue, because its a McGuffin plot that thinks it's more than that.  (See risk of rain plot development, or lack thereof)Buy this game on sale, if nothing else.  Its short 2-3 hour campaign is just long enough to excite, and leaves you eager for more.

Posted: September 7, 2015
												Would definitely recommend, but once again with many games on Steam it's only worth buying when it is at 20 cents. About 1.5 hours on first playthrough and thus the only thought going through my head was that it was equivalent to a really well made flash game online. Now that we're past that...Pros:Great opening, captured the retro feel in both the cutscene and sidescroll space shooter part, especially the forced death trope was done nicely. Gameplay is smooth, fun, and rewarding. It definitely takes inspiration from VVVVV though, but no problem there. Sound is amazing, the soundtrack is great for a 20 cent game. Also a nice bit of collectibles that are well hidden, so it is good for speedruns too.Cons:A bit short so once again buy it on the cheap. The idea of the teleport gun is somewhat cliche and some parts (such as the first part of the final boss fight) felt like a lame flash game made by some 12 year old, in which the boss has only 2 moves and both are really easy to avoid. Overall this game is mostly fun aside from a few "eh" moments, so buy it on sale.

Posted: September 7, 2015
												I don't agree that this game is anything like Super Metroid or Cave Story. Don't expect to upgrade your teleporter or gun, gain extra abilties like double jumping or branch into different areas as I have not encountered anything like that half an hour into the game but do not be surpirsed if it does show up. If anything, I would describe it as Super Meat Boy (Lite!) with Portal, although with a different physics mechinic in place of flinging.It's not kidding when it describes its other elements, though. It really is a refliex-heavy game. Often, the player may solve the puzzle long before he or she actually completes it because of the timing and aim required for the exeuction. It's honestly pretty satisifying, as a result, to get through a room because I managed to not only figure out the crazy, over-elobrate plan where I need to let some beam idle for 4.5 seconds before activating the second beam, destorying a boulder on the far right, teleporting to a platform on the left using the first teleporter, waiting for the first beam to deactivate (as beams block each other), and then using the second beam to get to the door.  This, however, can be frustrating if a player wishes to rush through the game or something. That is all the game has going for it.The chiptune music doesn't really motivate players to take their time, being ridicalously reptitive and loud, and the setting and story isn't memorable or worth paying attention to so far in my playthrough. I do not even know the name of my pro- oh, it's Yuri. My male protagonist's name is a common tag for lesbian storylines in manga. Hooray. The artstyle is, well, more of what you see can see in the store page.It's fun but nothing more than an extended flash game to me. It doesn't have the humor of Portal and so the only really motivating to keep playing is to complete more puzzles. Get it when it goes on sale for less than 50 cents.

Posted: September 10, 2015
												A nice little platformer game that combines a Portal-like idea with 2D platforming genre. It took me 2 and a half hours to beat it, though there are achievements to beat it under an hour and to beat it under 20 minutes. That may sound short, and I have no idea how one is supposed to beat this game under 20 minutes, but for what this game is, it could have been bad if it lasted longer. Overall, this game is good and quite fun.Side note: There are two 2D space shooting segments, one at the beginning of the game and one as a second (last) phase of the final boss fight. Keep in mind that this game *is* a 2D platforming game, so don't get confused, angry, discouraged or something else like that when you find yourself in space. It's okay.

Posted: September 9, 2015
												Out There Somewhere is a laid back puzzle platformer. The main mechanic is a teleportation gun which allows you to teleport where you shoot. The gun is similar to the one in The Swapper but time doesn't slow down when you fire it and you can't make multiple copies. The difference is that this teleportation gun preserves momentum. So if you fire it at a wall and jump right before the projectile hits you'll be jumping when you teleport.This leads to some interesting gameplay the first time through and some very interesting exploring on the second playthrough. The game clocks in at about 2-3 hours for the first playthough but it's almost better the second time through when you're better with the mechanics. It has a couple shmup sections but they are brief, which is bad if you're a shmup fan but good if you suck at them like I do.Overall I really enjoyed this game. If you like puzzle platformers with interesting mechanics I'd definitely recommend this to you.

Posted: July 3, 2015
												The thinking man's platformer game.Yes this game is short, but it has everything you want out of the mechanics. It makes you think, and lets you have fun. When you solve a certain room/puzzle the game lets you know you did well with an achievement, which is both corny and delightful.While this game is not open like VVVVVV, it has many of the same basic charms. Every screen is like a small puzzle, and you can not get stuck where the game experience has not taught you the skills required to succeed in the later parts of the game.It looked like there could be more from this game, and I would be happy to see it. Many of the puzzles were good and never repeated quite the same way twice. The two (three?) boss fights were interesting enough.I'll probably replay the game to try for 100%, even though there was not a progress label, but I did notice I missed a few things on my first run.

Posted: August 1, 2015
												Short puzzle platformer.Your character fall on a planet while chasing the big bad, and has to find parts to repair it.You have a gun that teleports you to the place your projectile hits, which is a really well used mechanic throughout the game.Pros:- The visuals are nice if you like pixel art- The controls are tight and responsive- Great soundtrack- The achievments inspire you to try different things giving the game a nice replayability- Charming characters and the story is nice throwback to more simple days of heroes and villains.Cons:- Short, you may finish it in under an hour in your first playthrough- May get boring to after, finishing more than once- Some rooms require a lot of of trial and error, which can get tiresome after a whileA must but if you like platformers.8,5

Posted: July 3, 2015
												Amazing game, worth way more than 20 cents. I think the 5 dollars is a reasonable price. It's fun albeit short, and plays smoothly. You should beat it in approximately 1 and a half hours on your first playthrough, but if you try to get all the achievements you'll be playing for a lot longer. Developers: make a sequel. I really enjoy this style, especially since the actual Metroid series isn't doing so great at the moment, this made me feel a bit of that feeling again, of exploration, adventure and space.The platforming is certainly different, but reminds me a bit of shinesparking, especially the really difficult sections.I personally haven't played cave story so I can't compare it to that, and I feel like the only thing really taken from portal was the teleport gun, so as far as I'm concerned, if you like metroid then certainly get this game. This games only downfall was its length, and I would happily play more like this. One of the best aspects they used from Metroid was sequence breaking. This is when you speed run and find ways to skip certain sections of the game (kinda neat how one of the achievements is exactly this, Shortcut) or have an item earlier in the game than you are supposed to (Daredevil). Finding out these things on your own, is what makes this game like metroid.One let down I felt was the text. Now I understand how complicated the portal gun is, and that the text is mostly necessary, but I felt that I didn't connect to the maini character as well. Super Metroid is a classic example of a game that needs almost no text, in fact the only text is at the beginning to explain what happened in the previous two games. But this is only a minor complaint, and a tip for the Devs if you are planning to make a sequel.Nonetheless, this game is very enjoyable, and I'd just like to say thank you for helping me connect with Metroid again. To everyone else, I highly recommend this game, especially for the price it is right now.

												Love it. It`s like Portal meets Metroid. You are a lone astronaut that crashed on an unknown planet where you have to survive by thinking you way through many platforming puzzles, armed only with your trusty teleport gun. The 2D perspective is key here and thanks to the clear 16 bit graphics these 2 create an excellent contrast and dimension for navigation puzzles. The soundtrack is amazing and keeps your blood flowing and your brain working. And your brain should keep working cause puzzles start easy and tend to get harder with each new screen passing. A must play for any fans of Portal or platformer puzzle games.

Posted: December 6, 2015
												When i first got this game (in the bundle to be exsact)  i thought it'd be a 10 minute game, but boy was i wrong.The games main gimmick of teleporting makes room for so many secrets and puzzles, and when you get the the gauss gun it allows you to dispose of monsters at a grindy pace, but if you ignore every checkpoint and find the room titled "you are so god damn stubborn" after you get the guass gun, and getting the upgrade for it in there turns it into a machine gun.Then there's the achievements, some are easy, some are hard, some ask for skill, some promote speedrunning, some promote you to kill everything you see, some are pointless, and some ask for collecting Ancient alien artifacts and Abandoned cores. all in all it's a great game, well worth the small amount of money you have to pay to get it, jsut make sure your good at puzzle-platformers and old arcade space shooters.10/10 would rage at dying just to get a collectible to make the end of the game easier on myself again.

												The is kind of deceptive!  It starts as a classic arcade shooter style game, but once you lose that bullet hell, you start the platformer part of the game to make an attempt to repair your ship and get back into the space battle.  Armed with your trusty teleport gun, you have to find ship parts and character upgrades.  It's a fun time, but it's also fairly confusing at times.  It can be frustrating, and you may find it too difficult to navigate some of the platformer screens.  Overall, I like it, and I think you'll like it, too.
