Posted: August 15, 2015
												I bought this game not thinking very much of it at the time. When I got into the game my view for Out There Somewhere changed drastically. I found myself loving this game. Out There Somewhere mixes a bullet hell arcade shooter with a platformer. All of this is done with well crafted sprites and backgrounds and is accompanied by a stellar 8 bit soundtrack that never seems to get repetitive.Out There Somewhere excells with its platforming and space combat. However the platforming combat was quite dull and the characters movements were a bit sharp at times. Beyond that the teleportation gun added a fun addition to the 2D platforming style and allowed there to be puzzles in the game.The game is about an hour long but has replay value for those who want to complete everything. When I got stuck on certain areas I wasn't stuck for long as the puzzles are relatively easy. Overall I enjoyed this game and I recommend this game to all platforming fans, 8bit fans and indie fans. Out There Somewhere is a fun twist on the classic 8bit metroidvania platformer.Score: 7/10While having good graphics and a great soundtrack the platforming was a bit stiff and this game does not stand out from others of the same genre, but still a fun game nonetheless.

Posted: June 12, 2015
												I got this amazing game for $0.18.This is the cheapest game I've ever bought, yet it's fun as hell!You earn trading cards too, so you practically earn your money back with cards you can sell if you buy this game on sale.96% off of a game that's amazing! I love it.Pros:• Hours of fun!• Amazingly cheap on Steam Summer Sale! $0.18 (or $0.19 depending where you live)!• You get trading cards which you can craft badges from, or sell them and earn more money than what you paid for the game.• Levels don't seem repetitive as there are new items and mechanics that appear every so often.Cons:• Awkward controls and you can't change them.• No settings in pause menu. You can only change settings on the main menu.• The game just shows a black screen infinitely when you launch it after you've bought it. You have to reboot/restart your computer in order to play the game for the first time.• The friendly aliens that you can talk to have no purpose except sometimes revealing information while most of the times they say something utterly useless.• Too difficult at some points. I just rage quit because I can't complete a level, lol.The cons aren't that bad. I bloody love this game!It's a crime for a game so good to be so cheap, even on Steam Summer Sale.

Getting those may require more meticulous search or a walkthrough, but I don't see a point in doing that."Inspired by" Metroid and Cave Story doesn't mean it is even remotely comparable to those. Unlike these games, it is short, mostly linear, only has few health and one gun upgrade, rudimentary story and mostly focused on jumping puzzles, not fighting.But at least it did not overstay its welcome.

Posted: March 2, 2016
												Let me open by saying this game is cheap, but is it worth the price tag?Yup.I recently played(and reviewed) a similar puzzle platformer, VVVVV or some nonsense, which I didn't find was to my liking.  As such I had some apprehension about Out There Somewhere.  I'll tell you that was some misplaced anxiety.  This game has a teleport mechnic that allows it to progress beyond simple muscle reflex puzzles and actually assess all the factors on a screen before proceeding with a solution.  After I completed the game, I felt satisfied.  I felt like I had accomplished some pretty interesting puzzle platforming, and I felt like I kind of wanted to play it through again.All that being said, this game isn't very long.  I don't know how much time I spent playing it, currently, but I think it was about an hour(Edit: 54 mins...)  which was actually perfect since I was on a flight and after I finished we were close to landing.  I see myself playing this again on my return trip and probably enjoying it just as much.One interesting thing I noticed in the options was the feature to turn on a timer, which seems an interesting little contraption to let you time your runs.  There's also a few areas I can think of where I may have been able to explore but they were early in the game before I really learned the capabilities of the teleporter gun.That's another bit that's interesting.  They don't throw new items at you through the game to make places accessible, with the exception of a gun near the beginning.  Anything you are able to accomplish late game with the teleporter you can do at the start... provided you grasp the concept fast enough.  The gun you obtain later is really only to destroy blocks and enemies, but it seemed to me (nearly) every screen could potentially be accomplished without killing a single enemy.The last bit I'll mention is that I played this game entirely on the Steam Controller, I've yet to find a platformer that doesn't work well with it, but I'll say playing a game on the plane was MUCH more comfortable with a controller in hand, rather than playing the part of a contortionist to access the keyboard wedged in front of me, though this is just commentary and doesn't affect my review of the game. Addition: OK, so since I was in an airplane and didn't pay for wifi, steam didn't register the time I'd played the game and wouldn't let me post a review with 0 minutes logged.  I started up a new game and can confirm in the 12 minutes of extra play time I found 3 screens I didn't even register existed on my first play through within the 'tutorial' section of the game.  So if you happen to be an achievement collector, or just like the game you can easily double that hour play time going through with a replay. Its worth the standard price(which is cheap as it is,) but if you find this game on sale, don't hesitate to nab it if you enjoy puzzle games or plaformers.  It's got some interesting mechanics.

Posted: June 30, 2015
												Im not to big on platformer puzzle games. But I really love this game. The concept of a teleport gun gave the level design alot of potential, and the developers definitely took advantage of most of this potential. Although some puzzles in the game could be completely by passed by either time a jump just right or soaring across a good chunck of the map by leaping off of a giant beacon tower thing, most of them were really engaging. Some of them really made me stop and think and plan things out. And most of the levels not only required you to think about the puzzle, but also made you react while performing this level. This concept isnt new, but it is in the game and really complements the gameplay. Being such a short game as well, the ending boss battle comes very quickly. The entire game took me 50 minutes for me to complete on my first attempt, but the boss battle was insane. A good kind of insane. And although very difficult in my opinion, it was definitely one of the most enjoyable boss battles I have encountered.     I got the game on sale for 19 cents, but the game is definitley worth its full $5. I would have loved to pay the full $5 dollars to support the developers and get some more content! But it is for sure worth your money.

Posted: September 5, 2015
												This game is everything I have ever wanted in a short, cheap Metroidvania puzzle platformer. Don't buy it for $5, but for $0.19 it's a steal. A very cool and not at all gimmicky teleport gun mechanic, controller support, and a campaign that takes 90-120 min if you don't know what you're doing, 60-90 min to 100% if you know what you're doing, and 15-25 min to speedrun if you know what you're doing. I've played through the game start to finish about 5-7 times and I still don't have all the achievements. The collectibles are extremely fun and there's only one that I had to look up where to find it (the 11th core). All in all, I recommend this game to any fan of Metroidvania games and puzzle platformers. My only complaint is that backtracking is severely limited, but it's OK because the game is so short. Great replayability, great value, great game. 9/10.

Posted: September 5, 2015
												*NOTE: This review was written by an individual who purchased the item at the time when it was  obscenely discounted (96%)!*Portal + Metroid (NES) = Out There Somewhere.  This was a great little game, and I would have loved to have seen it last longer.  It took me about 2 hours to beat the game, but there is a marginal amount of replayability if you push for acquiring all of the Steam achievements.The game is 2D Metroid (NES) style and is very linear, with a few optional detours for special items if you feel up to it.  Each side-scrolling screen you pass into plays out as increasingly difficult Portal-type, platforming puzzles.  Near the 2/3 mark of the game, there were perhaps 2 screens that were difficult enough that I had to cave in and check a walkthrough for and when I found the answer, it was a slap-upside-the-head DERP answer I felt like I should have obviously known, but some spots do require some brain-power, which were refreshing.*DISCLAIMER: Everyone and their dead dog needs to buy this game while it is only 19 cents to purchase!  That being said, although it is a ton of fun, I personally would not recommend it for the full $4.99 price tag due to the overall lack of bang for your buck.*

Posted: September 7, 2015
												I don't agree that this game is anything like Super Metroid or Cave Story. Don't expect to upgrade your teleporter or gun, gain extra abilties like double jumping or branch into different areas as I have not encountered anything like that half an hour into the game but do not be surpirsed if it does show up. If anything, I would describe it as Super Meat Boy (Lite!) with Portal, although with a different physics mechinic in place of flinging.It's not kidding when it describes its other elements, though. It really is a refliex-heavy game. Often, the player may solve the puzzle long before he or she actually completes it because of the timing and aim required for the exeuction. It's honestly pretty satisifying, as a result, to get through a room because I managed to not only figure out the crazy, over-elobrate plan where I need to let some beam idle for 4.5 seconds before activating the second beam, destorying a boulder on the far right, teleporting to a platform on the left using the first teleporter, waiting for the first beam to deactivate (as beams block each other), and then using the second beam to get to the door.  This, however, can be frustrating if a player wishes to rush through the game or something. That is all the game has going for it.The chiptune music doesn't really motivate players to take their time, being ridicalously reptitive and loud, and the setting and story isn't memorable or worth paying attention to so far in my playthrough. I do not even know the name of my pro- oh, it's Yuri. My male protagonist's name is a common tag for lesbian storylines in manga. Hooray. The artstyle is, well, more of what you see can see in the store page.It's fun but nothing more than an extended flash game to me. It doesn't have the humor of Portal and so the only really motivating to keep playing is to complete more puzzles. Get it when it goes on sale for less than 50 cents.

Posted: September 7, 2015
												First off, I bought this game on a whim for when it was only 19 cents, because I had some spare money from the steam sale, and this looked like something that wasn't a ripoff of Minecraft, see 7 cent 'Uncrowded'.I played it through to completion, and though while the puzzles are phenomenal, using a set of mechanics that really support the platforming, and give a whole new spin on it by the end, there are somethings I dislike about this game, and will mention below.First off, all the tacked on mechanics, i.e. the space battles, which are the first and last things that happen in the game.  They're contrived, really have no point, and if the game ended with the final battle that tested your skills, then that would be amazing, not the 'This is my final form' bs.And second off, the story will rub you the wrong way.  It will.  I recommend skipping all the dialogue, because its a McGuffin plot that thinks it's more than that.  (See risk of rain plot development, or lack thereof)Buy this game on sale, if nothing else.  Its short 2-3 hour campaign is just long enough to excite, and leaves you eager for more.

												Oh... My... GodYey Yes Yes all the yaaaassGot this game for 19 cents, and it was more than worth it.So, I'm gonna tell you guys why I loved it so much.Visuals- One word: Pretty. Posted: April 22, 2015
												After enjoying completing the game with 100% and just some cards left to collect, I decided to give this fine piece of software a review.So what's this game anyway? Basically it's a platformer, with minor Shoot'em Up parts both at the beginning and the end of the game. Armed with a teleport gun and a space suit you control Captain Yuri on his journey to defeat the evil Grigori.Simple control scheme: arrow keys and 3 others, Z X C by default, Europeans might want to swap Z with Y prior to starting. The game does have controller support, I used a keyboard though and had no problems.Over the course of my several playthroughs and experiments I only encountered 1 or 2 minor bugs you wouldn't experience without specifically looking for it. Even if, none of them was game breaking. Otherwise it's got smooth and clean animations, perfect hitboxes and overall fair difficulty. There's no real tutorial but is streamlined on directs you perfectly through the mechanics, the growing complexity should be no problem for the average player.If you want all achievements though, you're in for a tougher challenge, brace yourself and activate your thinker.As for the design, it's an adorable small indie treasure, you won't get 10 hours of excitement but instead you'll get challenging fun packed into a small platformer. Nothing looks out of place, everything fits into this colourfully bright (but not bilindingly bright) small universe. Even the music is brilliant for such a small game, it's repetetive but it doesn't get boring, this way it's even fun waiting for the "delay" Achievement while doing something else. Only downside is there's no transition when the BGM changes but hey, it's not like that would hurt anyoneMy first playthrough took me an hour and roughly 15 minutes, the only thing that really got on my nerves was clicking through Yuris messages on my playthroughs after the first one...Bottom line: whatever you pay, it's a bargain

Posted: August 14, 2015
												This game can be pretty enjoyable for a few hours, and it's somewhat memorable. I'll go over its notable aspects here.StoryThe story is pretty much as basic as it can get, cliché even. However, I was satisfied with how they handled it in implementation. Whoever designed the story segments was well aware that nobody would care. Instead of shoving some bland exposition down your throat while you slump lifelessly over your keyboard and wonder if playing through this game is a commitment you're willing to make, it provides the story in short, quickly skippable (or quickly readable) lines of text. You can get through it in a few seconds, and you're not missing much if you ignore it entirely. The gist is that you're a spaceman on a foreign planet and need to kill some guy. Narrative gold.GraphicsThe pixel art isn't bad. It's not anything special. It's not too repetitive. Sprites gel pretty well with each other, but tile sprites stick strictly to their square shape and corners aren't adorned in any way to reduce the jaggedness of such defined tiles. All of the main character's animations are so beautifully fluid, though, and the walking animation is adorable.AudioThe music is pretty average. Sometimes it gets better, but it gets redundant and loses its charm as it loops. In the game's store page description, it throws around names such as Cave Story. If they're going to tote around a reference to a game like that, I think it's only fair to interpret that as a standard to hold their game to. It falls abysmically below this standard.ControlsControls feel fine and function as intended. Some precision is required, but it's not unforgiving.MechanicsThis is the good bit. The game is based on traversing through puzzles using a simple mechanic: You can fire projectiles horizontally. When these projectiles impact something, you are teleported to the point of impact. Combine this with precision platforming and quick thinking, and you can pull off some neat stunts. New objects are introduced that add more depth to the puzzles. For example, there are colored beams that can destroy, obstruct, or even redirect your shots. These can be toggled by switches or obstructed by objects. I think the store page description's comparison of this game to Portal is actually pretty fair. While the mechanics and dimensionality are different, they require the same kind of problem solving and reflex. The teleportation gun is ineffective as a weapon, however, which brings us to...CombatAt first, you have to avoid enemies entirely because you lack a means of removing them. At some point, your character aquires a new tool: a firearm. Now, the first thing you'd want to do is go out and start packing heat at anything that looks like it could accommodate a few bullets, but you'd soon find out that your shiny new baby isn't very empowering. There are only a few types of enemies. Some exist to serve as barriers in the puzzles, and your weapon is only a tool for removing them. The rest exist just so that there are enemies. They're usually not challenging or unique, but I suppose they do add some variance. You can collect hidden items to increase the number of hits you can take, but health isn't really something that needs to be managed. Other than the boss battle, the combat isn't explored past this.I'd like to point out that the store page description also points to Super Metroid, and again interpret such a reference as justification to compare these games both ways. Again, it's not even a close comparison.At the end, you have to utilize both your teleport gun and firearm to battle the main antagonist by moving around the room to dodge attacks and position yourself to have a clear shot. This part is actually quite well done, but I was not at all prepared for what came next. That's covered in...Level Design and ProgressionPuzzles can be pretty creative. They're typically not too difficult, and checkpoints are generous enough to ensure that you're not getting frustrated about replaying the same sections. Puzzles frequently introduce new ways to utilize the tools that you already have, rarely feeling repetitive. If you're observant and think a little more to get to alternate paths, you can get rewarded with items, even if they're not always useful. The puzzles are overall satisfying and engaging.The largest and ugliest flaw of this game is its length. When I reached the end, I was unsure if I was just misinterpreting what was going on. It was just so absurdly short. It was a decent ride, though.Now, I'd like to explain how it pulls off this ending. In the last section, I mentioned a boss battle in which you use what you've gained to take out the main antagonist. After he's defeated, you get out of there, walk a screen or two, and then it slams into you so unnervingly hard. Suddenly, the quite enjoyable puzzle platformer I was playing now has me careening through space in my ship, toe to toe with another.I am now suddenly playing a side-scrolling shoot 'em up sequence. There is no similar puzzle mechanic or anything. There's just dodging and mashing to spam bullets. I personally do not enjoy shmups. I barely play them, and when I do, they do not entertain me. I didn't know that I was in for this when I played through a puzzle-oriented "action platformer," as the store page describes it.Anyway, maybe I just suck at these things, but I didn't have the motivation to power through that final boss battle. I got someone else to help me out with the mashing part, just for the sake of completion.RatingI've decided to rate this game positively for two reasons: I picked it up on sale for a nice price, and the majority of the game's mechanics and level design were pleasant and impressive.TL;DRI originally intended for this to be brief, but yet again, I rambled far too long. Basically, the only good selling point is the great puzzle-based gameplay. The game is incredibly short (a few hours at best), so it's best to pick it up on sale. I wouldn't advise paying for it at full price unless you're an afficionado for this stuff.

Posted: September 11, 2015
												It's a really nice, little game. The pixel art is interesting through adding little effects here and there, like how the background is always moving, yet it's not distracting. It makes a cool visual. The game's setting has an oddly not-so-desolate, metroid-like, planet as a setting, which I'm also a big fan of. Another thing I enjoyed was that all the NPC's were nice little guys, and came some interesting lines, if you went the distance to talk to them. The soundtrack is also really nice, it fits the space theme without being boring. The puzzles (stages that have you use a portal gun to advance) were difficult, but never so hard that I gave up. That was a big one for me, and it probably had to do with how well you could see the puzzle in whole, and the simple mechanics. I really love the puzzles. The story is... not very exisistent. There is some bad guy, Grigori (ugly fellow), who is a total jerk, he blew up your ship, you wreck, so now you have to find him on this planet you wrecked on (I don't know why the bad guy is there, I think we were trying to go to the planet to attack him, buy it's not well explained). It does provide an objective, but it isn't very complicated. In whole, I bought the game for $0.16 (an awesome price), and was surprised. However, the game is really short. My 3 hours were all I needed to beat the game. But, if you're okay with short games, it's a lovely experience. I was only upset at the length to be honest. It feels incomplete,  like a greenlight game. I really want more cool puzzles and funny creatures, but then the games over. I also beleive that with more time it could have a neat little plot to help tie the story together. I just want more. An update with a story that goes somewhere (maybe to other planets) would solve all my issues with this game. There are collectables and an achievement for completing the game under an hour, which make the game more replayable in its defense, but it just won't fill the void.

Posted: July 1, 2015
												Very begrudgingly, I recommend this game. Very begrudgingly! I did enjoy this game. It had fun mechanics, a nice look. Some good little humor thrown in here and there, but it didn't really have too much of a drive towards it. Near the end of the game I forgot I still had a nemesis to beat... and that his name was Grigorio. I was just concentrating on getting that orb... thing. And the main bulk of the gameplay is Portal-esque 2D puzzle platforming, and it's puzzling that doesn't just require know-how, it also requires good timing and patience. This game has a big difficulty curve, and you really need to think outside the box in order to beat it. My biggest complaint would have to be... the last boss. The game only has you do the 2D sideshooter for the first minute of the game, then expects you to hop back in knowing exactly what you're doing, right when you have to kill the final bloody boss. Thank you game, I have a brain, but not as fast of an adaptable one as you may think I do. With the main push towards patience, timing, and creative thinking- Out There Somewhere pushes it right out the door with the fast-paced, shoot-em-up with the final boss, and I did not like it. At all. But for what it's worth, the main bulk of the game and its gameplay is very nice. A fine throwback to old-school Nintendo games... but with a much nicer look.

Posted: April 22, 2015
												Got this game for 21 cents. Best deal ever!This game is like metriod meets a portal gun. Except a little diffrent. When you shoot your gun when the "teleshot" as the game calls it, hits a wall, you instantley teleport there. Sounds simple, huh? Well just like portal, it gets crazy. Your teleshot preserves movement, so if you fire and then jump at the last second, you will jump at that other place you just teleported to. This can be used to jump, fire, then as soon as you hit the ground jump again to do basically a double jump. Theres also a bunch more mechanics as well, such as 3 diffrent beams, enemies, glass and wood, mirrors, and a bunch of other stuff. Also the achievments are pretty challanging (all but one) to get and can add hours of gameplay if you're into that. Overall, great mechanic, great soundtrack, love the metriod style, and challanging achievments. 9/10.Edit: theres a HUGE difficulty spike at the final boss, one misclick and you're screwed. Thought i'd mention that.

Posted: November 5, 2015
												A very unique and enjoyable platformer centered around using a teleport gun, almost like a 2D Portal. The puzzles are well-crafted and clever, with more than one way through many of them. The biggest downside for me was the length of the game or, more accurately, the lack thereof. This game is very short. The 1.6 hours I have on record was a single full playthrough, beginning to end. The only replay value is in the achievements, if you're into that sort of thing. If you're like me, and couldn't care less about the achievements, you may find yourself thankful that you got the game on sale and only paid $0.19 for it. I recommend the game - not the price. $5 is a little steep for a game that's over so quickly. What's there is worth playing, but it's not worth the asking price. Even with as challenging as some of the puzzles are, requiring multiple attempts, I managed to beat the game in 90 minutes - and I'm pretty terrible at platformers.Get it on sale, and you won't be disappointed. Pay full price, and you might find yourself a little irritated at the shortness of the game.

It's quite entertaining, the gameplay mechanics are obviously well thought out, controls are responsive and suit this type of platformer very well. Visually and audially, the artistic integrity is to be respected if not admired. Posted: June 18, 2015
												Out There Somewhere is an action-platformer where the primary gimmick is a gun that teleports you to where you shoot it. It's quite short — my first playthrough clocked in at just over an hour — but even so there's a surprising amount of depth in the game's platforming challenges, as well as a few secrets here and there to discover. I legitimately tried looking for as many as I could in that first playthrough, only to discover at the end that I had missed around half of them. Additionally, for the speedrun inclined, there is an option to display a timer, and it is entirely possible to finish the game in about 11 minutes.The game doesn't feature a complicated plot — it's the simple tale of a space cop who has to shoot up an evil alien dude. If you're a huge nostalgic memelord you might enjoy the blatant Zero Wing references. Graphically, the game resembles Cave Story with extra frames of fluidity added to the sprite animations. It's nice to look at in general, and the alien friends are charming. The chiptune music is also pretty good, save for one annoying track near the beginning of the game that seemed to only last like 20 seconds before looping.There are several minor issues I suppose I should mention. For one, there are many screens that cannot be returned to once they're left, and frequent checkpoints, while normally a boon, mean that if you've missed a collectible, you've probably also lost the opportunity to get it. Considering that health upgrades are part of these collectibles and you only have one health to begin with, it is entirely possible to end up past a point of no return where you have to finish the game as a one-hit-wonder, or just restart because it's too annoying to handle.Along with that, there's also an achievement that requires having 30 teleport gun shots on screen at once; the only apparent way to do that causes a cacophony of ear-piercing sound effects unless the game is muted. I can't imagine this being an oversight, and since I'm a jerk I found it sort of amusing, but still ow.Nitpicking aside, Out There Somewhere is a solid title for anyone in want of bite-sized platforming fun. It is also literally $0.19 during the Steam Summer Sale, and the 3 Steam Trading Cards it drops should recoup the bulk of that price. This game is a must buy before the sale ends.p.s. i just noticed that the developer's logo mascot changes colors on every start up and that is an odd feature i don't know if anyone but me would notice but i like it thank you

Posted: November 3, 2015
												There's a lot of junk on Steam, specially in the 2-49ct category. I bought this game for 19ct and I'm overwhelmed at how good it is. It's basially an 8-bit style platformer where Portal-style puzzles are solved with the help of a teleportation gun. The graphics are neat, the dialogs funny and the music is very retro, though it could use some polishing (the transitions between the loops are not very smooth and the music start to be very repetitive quite fast). Nevertheless, Out There Somewhere is a nice, challenging little game with NES-style graphics and music. Grab it if you see it in the bargain bin: it's totally worth it, or of course at full price, if you're a retro puzzle platformer geek. You sure won't regret it!

Posted: March 19, 2016
												Out There Somewhere is a fun, indie, action, puzzle, adventure platformer that is SUPER fun. It's very unique, and reminds me a lot of Portal and You Have to Win the Game.In Out There Somewhere, you are Yuri, who has gone out to kill Grigori, when your ship crashes on a mysterious, and mildly hostile planet. You soon learn that Grigori is on the planet as well, on your search for the one thing that can get your ship running again: the Light Orb. It is a very good plot, and it controls really well. I found it easier to play with controller, rather than with the keyboard. The achivements in the game aren't that difficult to get, and the game doesn't really take that long to beat. There are two types of guns that you weild: the teleportation gun and the guass gun. The teleportation gun is pretty self-explanitory, and the guass gun can be used for killing enemies and breaking "unstable" blocks. Also, this game has an amazing soundtrack. It's one of ny favourites in a long time, but Skyrim, Mario, and Zelda's soundtracks are still better.Overall, this game was a LOT better than I first imagined. The game is also child-friendly, so people of all ages can play. I highly recommend this game to everybody. You won't be disapointed.

Posted: March 24, 2016
												Ridiculously tight, well implemented 2D platformer that runs with the idea of a teleporter gun & mashes it with near perfect controls, puzzle design, and learning curve. You'll die, sure, but it's because you suck, rather than the game wanting to make you feel like you suck. What makes this is inspired is how well its gimmick, the teleporter gun, is implemented - you fire it, a bullet goes off traveling, and when that bullet hits something, you'll be instantly transported to that point - continuing your current momentum. That's what's key. You get eased into these simple 'jump up & shoot towards this platform you can't jump across to' puzzles & then suddenly you're jumping up, firing it off across to a wall, landing & jumping again in a different direction just as it hits, then repeating all that immediately in a different direction, but with none of the stress of a lot of these dumb modern-retro platformers.  It rocks.

Posted: March 24, 2016
												A really clever little game with interesting momentum based puzzles, amazing music, and fabulous pixel art.The puzzles can sometimes be tough to pull off or just be downright confounding when you try to start working your way through it, but it's a good, refreshing kind of frustration (akin to Portal's frustration) that leaves you feeling like a genius and a platforming master by the time you get through it.The spaceship portions are tough but simple bullet hells that killed me a LOT, but I just blame my poor dodging skills and it's by no fault of the game's mechanics or controls.Although I was able to "finish" the game in around a total of 2-ish hours, I still have a looong way to go; especially if I hope to make a dent in the considerable list of achievements (and as if to add a cherry on top of this, the achievements also have more of that gorgeous pixel art! I love it so much).And along with everything else, a big bonus was the price I paid for it - just $0.49!So this game gets a really solid 8/10 from me.

Posted: March 22, 2016
												To put it simply: 'Out There Somewhere' is fun.Challenging while casual, difficult yet enjoyable, Out There Somewhere is a story-filled platformer with puzzles and monsters that left me feeling successful and with a sense of pride.Out There Somewhere is a platformer in which your character goes on a mission to defeat the evil space conquerer named Grigori after your spaceship is shot out of orbit. With your trusty teleport gun, get through dangerous puzzles and monsters to once and for all defeat Grigori, and save the universe from domination. I think that's the story.

Posted: June 1, 2016
												Out There Somewhere is a wonderful game. It reminds me of Super Meatboy mixed with Cave Story and a little bit of the classic Metroid games. It has an amazing ost, the best 8 bit ost since Shovel Knight. The telaporting gun thing works really well and is used for some very challenging puzzles, that will most likely A: Make you relize the game is a little unforgiving to B: I want to ragequit, but I can't since the game is too addicting. I guess the only problem could be the 8 bit graphics since thats pretty overdone at this point by most old school 8 bit indie games like this trying to recreate what it was like to be a gamer in the 80s or 90s, but graphics are not everything if a game is fun. If theres any thing I'v learn from games like Earthbound, CaveStory, Undertale, and the old NES Mega Man games its that a game does not need to focus on the graphics if the gameplay is fun. Yes a game does need to have graphics that are appealing, not saying that any of those games are not appealing, its just that Out There Somewheres graphics should not be the foirst thing you at as critizism since that would make you miss out on a really fun not very well known indie game. It is currently 49 cents Steam so I recommed you check it out and buy it.

												This game is short but smart, with replayability value (for completionists) up the wazoo. The core gameplay mechanics are solid and polished, the pixel art is tight and sexy, and the music is very sweet – it fits the mood, too, and never gets annoying. Which is always a good sign for music."Out There Somewhere" is a 2D action puzzle platformer that includes a teleport gun that quickly grows on you. Posted: October 16, 2015
												True to popular description, Out There Somewhere is highly reminiscent of classic retro-style platformers like Cave Story: it's fairly challenging, it isn't very long, it has catchy music, and it plays like a dream.The teleporting mechanic is difficult to master but rewarding once you get it down, so much so that you'll find yourself using it even when the situation doesn't call for it (much like we probably would if we could teleport around at will). The controls are tight, and unlike Cave Story's Quote, Captain Yuri doesn't feel very floaty when he jumps or falls. A lot of the platforming puzzles in this game involve well-timed drops that Super Smash Bros. Brawl-styled gravity would make far too easy to perform, so this is a very good thing.Out There Somewhere is great. Get yourself a copy!

												I got this amazing game for $0.18.This is the cheapest game I've ever bought, yet it's fun as hell!You earn trading cards too, so you practically earn your money back with cards you can sell if you buy this game on sale.96% off of a game that's amazing! I love it.Pros:• Hours of fun!• Amazingly cheap on Steam Summer Sale! $0.18 (or $0.19 depending where you live)!• You get trading cards which you can craft badges from, or sell them and earn more money than what you paid for the game.• Levels don't seem repetitive as there are new items and mechanics that appear every so often.Cons:• Awkward controls and you can't change them.• No settings in pause menu. You can only change settings on the main menu.• The game just shows a black screen infinitely when you launch it after you've bought it. You have to reboot/restart your computer in order to play the game for the first time.• The friendly aliens that you can talk to have no purpose except sometimes revealing information while most of the times they say something utterly useless.• Too difficult at some points. I just rage quit because I can't complete a level, lol.The cons aren't that bad. I bloody love this game!It's a crime for a game so good to be so cheap, even on Steam Summer Sale.

Posted: December 4, 2015
												Out There Somewhere is a nice puzzle platformer that genuinely feels like a mix of Cave Story and Portal. The game is pretty short - and it's fully possible to beat it within 20 minutes, which is one of the game's hardest challengest - but there's a bunch of things to collect that provides replay value. I got it for 17 cents when it was on sale, but it's honestly worth the money whatever the price.The music works with the setting and the graphics are done well and the gameplay is fair, but challenging. My only complaint is the shooting segments. While it's not hard to pick up on, it really clashes with the rest of the game's gameplay, and the fact that it's the final fight bizarre since your only experience with such segments is at the very beginning. But overall though, it's a great cheap game.

Posted: November 26, 2015
												Out There Somewhere is an okay little platform games with minimalistic retro pixel-based graphics and music. The game mechanics is based on jumping and a teleport gun that teleports you to whatever you shoot with it instantly. There are some blocks and beams that react differently to the teleport shot and you conserve momentum, so that if you jump before being teleported, you will be going up at your point of teleportation.It's a simple and decent mechanic. It may be a bit hard to understand at first, but you get the hang of it quickly, and when you do get the hang of it... the game ends.Yeah, the game is really short, I beat it in 32 minutes of game time. I didn't try to do a speed run or anything, I was just solving screens one after the other. Maybe there are optional paths I didn't check out, but it didn't feel like it. So, yeah, very short, but it is a very cheap game, so I won't complain, just adjust your expectations.

Posted: December 6, 2015
												When i first got this game (in the bundle to be exsact)  i thought it'd be a 10 minute game, but boy was i wrong.The games main gimmick of teleporting makes room for so many secrets and puzzles, and when you get the the gauss gun it allows you to dispose of monsters at a grindy pace, but if you ignore every checkpoint and find the room titled "you are so god damn stubborn" after you get the guass gun, and getting the upgrade for it in there turns it into a machine gun.Then there's the achievements, some are easy, some are hard, some ask for skill, some promote speedrunning, some promote you to kill everything you see, some are pointless, and some ask for collecting Ancient alien artifacts and Abandoned cores. all in all it's a great game, well worth the small amount of money you have to pay to get it, jsut make sure your good at puzzle-platformers and old arcade space shooters.10/10 would rage at dying just to get a collectible to make the end of the game easier on myself again.

												I've only played it a little bit, but so far I'm loving it.Great ship shooting gameplay, great platformer aspects, amazing soundtrack, there's a million things I like about this game.One thing I didn't like is that you can sometimes miss checkpoints, which causes a lot of backtracking. Also, when you first unlock the weapon that actually hurts enemies, it does little to no damage (considering it's a one-hit KO on you), and one of the first enemies you face after getting the gun is one that flies around trying to get you. It makes it a lot harder when those ones are around.It's still a great game.8/10

Posted: March 17, 2016
												If you're a fan of pixel art platform games there is no excuse not getting this game. It is pretty short but it's very appropriately priced and it has great replay value. The controls and mechanics are very fluid and the difficulty is well balanced; it's challenging but it never feels frustrating. The soundtrack is good and while the ending can feel a bit abrupt I never felt the story was the main focus of the game. Don't go into this expecting Undertale-level storytelling, but rather a really solid, mechanically challenging platformer.The only real downside I can think of is that the dialogue boxes could be smoother.

												Out There Somewhere is a great game. The game offers good soundtracks on each level. Posted: September 2, 2015
												Bought Out There Somewhere on sale for $0.19, it regularly sells for $4.99. It's worth the regular price, because I'd probably spend that much in quarters to beat it. I have 1.7 hours on record, and that was one playthrough to finish the game. The teleportation mechanic works well with the level designs. A few of the puzzles can be skipped easily with well placed portal shots, but they don't require enough effort to feel like more than small victories over what seems to be the planned route. A decent amount of that 1.7 hours was spent experimenting with routes through different areas, and found that the developers were a little bit amusingly playful, though I don't want to spoil the experiences for anybody who may be pleasantly annoyed by them.The game isn't really about fighting. It feels as though some schmup tutorial project was thrown into the project to add meat to the game, but its difficulty amounts to how quickly you can mash the fire button, especially with the large amount of life you're given during the schmup portions of the game. The Gauss gun is used in some decently challenging puzzles, but not really necessary for any combat.The music is reminiscent of Cave Story. I caught my head bobbing a few times, and had to look around to be sure nobody was up to catch my inadvertant dysrhythmic neck spasms.I described the movement on my twitch stream as being something between Super Mario Bros. 3 and Mega Man, with better air control than Mega Man, but maybe some more friction than SMB3. The controls feel tight and responsive, even though it requires about 1/4 to 1/2 of the game for me to develop a habit for good teleporter jumping.I finished this game wanting more. Definitely check this out if you enjoyed Cave Story, or any platformer that requires tight and precise movements using combinations of buttons.
